   Other labs: Lactic Acid:1.5 mmol/L
   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan: Ms. [**Known lastname **] is a 78 year old woman with a history of
   HTN and PVD s/p CVA who presents after mental status changes, anorexia,
   & progressive lethargy with a work-up concerning for multifocal
   pneumonia & UTI.
   .
   # Hypercarbic respiratoy failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection.   HCO3 38 on admission, not usually so high
   (baseline 30).  ? Aggressive diuresis. Potentially due to poor
   respiratory controller function secondary to overmedication, or poor
   respiratory muscle function. Could be due to prior C-spine injury
   causing phrenic nerve injury worsening respiratory dynamics. [**Month (only) 60**] also
   consider PE and infection/pneumonia. S/p tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**]
   incarcerated hernia repair and failure to wean.  Unclear if aspiration
   risk but on po diet at NS.  CXR with ? PNA vs volume overload.
    - Treat infection as above
    - Venturi FM
    - Discuss recent baseline labs / medication changes with [**Hospital1 169**] in AM
   - Check Depakote level
   - Check LFTs
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - CTA to evaluate for PE.
   - Treat infection (Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **]); Azithromycin added for atypicals
   - Urine legionella antigen; will d/c azithromycin if legionella
   negative.
   - Sputum / blood culture as able
   - BNP level
   .
   # Lethargy/AMS:  Lethargy and minimalizing localizing symptoms.
   Present work-up notable for +UA (with history of Cipro-R E.coli) and
   CXR which appears more volume over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile,
   without leukocytosis.  Family notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider
   aspiration, viral vs atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is
   definately contributing. Resolved with improvement in respiratory
   status.
   - Urine culture
    - On Venturi facemask now.
    - Valproic acid level
    - Hold Risperdal / Depakote given AMS
    - Monitor with serial VBGs
   - Access: get Picc and arterial line.
   .
   # UTI:  UA with hematuria. H/o Cipro-R E.coli.  Denies any complaints.
    - [**Last Name (un) **]/Vanco
    - Follow-up culture (adding from ICU)
   - Obtaining PM Hct due to hematuria
   .
   # Hypertension: On Diltiazem as outpatient.  Unclear if given today.
    - Will break into short-acting while unclear volume status (consider
   holding)
   .
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.  No ulcerations on exam.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   .
   # Bipolar disorder:  On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient.
    - Hold medications for AMS, plan to restart as able.
    - Check Depakote level; holding risperdal and depakote levels.
   .
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   .
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history. Will plan to discuss with daughter.  [**Name (NI) **] family,
   unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   .
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   .
   FEN: IVF o/n (monitor uop), replete electrolytes, NPO while on BiPAP
   - Clear liquids today and advance diet with improvement in mental
   status.
   .
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   Access: PIV
   .
   Code: DNR/DNI  (confirmed with patient upon arrival to ICU)
   .
   Communication: Patient & daughter
   .
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2107-3-6**] 09:30 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Based on the provided 24-hour progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, and a previous cerebrovascular accident (CVA). She was admitted to the ICU with mental status changes, anorexia, and progressive lethargy, and was found to have multifocal pneumonia and urinary tract infection (UTI).

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has hypercarbic respiratory failure, which is acute on chronic, and is suspected to be multifactorial, including chronic hypercarbia at baseline, excess volume, and infection.
2. Lethargy/Antisocial Personality Disorder (AMS): The patient is lethargic and has minimalizing localizing symptoms, which may be contributing to her AMS.
3. UTI: The patient has a urinary tract infection, which is suspected to be caused by E. coli, given her history of Cipro-resistant E. coli.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is controlled with Diltiazem, but it is unclear if she received the medication today.
5. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient has chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections, but no ulcerations were noted on examination.
6. Bipolar disorder: The patient is taking Risperdal and Depakote, but these medications are being held due to her AMS.
7. Diverticulosis: The patient has a history of lower gastrointestinal bleeding (LGIB), but is not currently experiencing symptoms.
8. Cerebrovascular accident (CVA): The patient has a history of CVA, but the extent of her deficits is unclear, and she is unable to provide further history.
9. Urinary incontinence: The patient has urinary incontinence at baseline, and a Foley catheter is in place.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure can worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory arrest or cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and pneumonia can lead to sepsis, which can cause organ failure and death.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia can worsen if not treated promptly and effectively, leading to respiratory failure and death.
4. UTI: The patient's UTI can spread to other parts of the body if not treated promptly and effectively, leading to sepsis and organ failure.
5. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension can worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiac failure and death.
6. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient's peripheral vascular disease can worsen if not managed properly, leading to limb loss or gangrene.
7. Bipolar disorder: The patient's bipolar disorder can worsen if not managed properly, leading to mood instability and suicidal behavior.
8. Diverticulosis: The patient's diverticulosis can worsen if not managed properly, leading to complications such as bleeding or perforation.
9. Cerebrovascular accident (CVA): The patient's CVA can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further brain damage or death.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for a variety of medical complications due to her underlying conditions. It is essential to manage her conditions properly to prevent these complications and improve her overall outcome.

1. Respiratory status: The patient is experiencing hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely due to a combination of chronic hypercarbia, excess volume, and potential infection. The patient is on Venturi facemask and requires further management to improve respiratory status.
2. Neurological status: The patient is lethargic and minimally localizing symptoms, which is concerning for aspiration, viral or atypical pneumonia, or hypercarbia. The patient's neurological status is improving with improvement in respiratory status.
3. Infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and a possible multifocal pneumonia. The patient's urine culture and sputum/blood culture are pending.
4. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension and is taking Diltiazem as an outpatient. The patient's blood pressure is 127/69 mmHg, which is within a normal range.
5. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient has chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections. The patient's peripheral vascular exam is not assessed.
6. Bipolar disorder: The patient is taking Risperdal and Depakote as an outpatient. The patient's medications are being held due to altered mental status.
7. Diverticulosis: The patient has a history of LGIB and is taking a bowel regimen. The patient's diverticulosis is not acutely inflamed.
8. s/p CVA: The patient has a history of CVA and is unable to provide further history. The patient's neurological deficit is unclear and will be discussed with the patient's daughter.
9. Urinary incontinence: The patient has urinary incontinence at baseline and has a Foley catheter in place.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure can worsen if not managed properly.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's multifocal pneumonia can progress and cause further respiratory distress.
3. UTI: The patient's UTI can spread to other parts of the body and cause sepsis.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension can worsen if not managed properly, potentially leading to cardiac complications.
5. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient's chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections can worsen if not managed properly, potentially leading to further complications.
6. Bipolar disorder: The patient's bipolar disorder can worsen if not managed properly, potentially leading to further neurological complications.
7. Diverticulosis: The patient's diverticulosis can worsen if not managed properly, potentially leading to further gastrointestinal complications.
8. s/p CVA: The patient's s/p CVA can worsen if not managed properly, potentially leading to further neurological complications.

The plan of care is to continue to manage the patient's respiratory status, treat the patient's infections, and monitor the patient's neurological and gastrointestinal status.

Summary:

The patient, a 78-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, and previous cerebrovascular accident, was admitted to the ICU with mental status changes, anorexia, and progressive lethargy. The patient has a suspected multifocal pneumonia and urinary tract infection, and is being treated with vancomycin and azithromycin. The patient is on a Venturi facemask and is being monitored for hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient has a history of chronic hypercarbia and is being treated with diuresis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen if not properly treated, leading to respiratory arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's suspected multifocal pneumonia and urinary tract infection may lead to sepsis if not properly treated, which can cause organ failure and death.
3. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen if not properly managed, leading to cardiovascular complications such as heart failure, stroke, and cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient's peripheral vascular disease may worsen if not properly managed, leading to chronic venous stasis changes, wound infections, and limb loss.
5. Cerebrovascular accident: The patient's previous cerebrovascular accident may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further neurological deficits and potential death.
6. Urinary tract infection: The patient's urinary tract infection may spread to the kidneys and cause sepsis, leading to organ failure and death.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's multifocal pneumonia may worsen if not properly treated, leading to respiratory failure, sepsis, and death.
8. Aspiration: The patient's suspected aspiration may lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and death if not properly treated.
9. Hypercarbia: The patient's hypercarbia may worsen if not properly treated, leading to respiratory failure, sepsis, and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed to maintain optimal oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Continue to treat the patient's suspected multifocal pneumonia and urinary tract infection with vancomycin and azithromycin, and consider adding additional antibiotics as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension with diuretics and antihypertensive medications, and consider adding additional medications as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's peripheral vascular disease and consider adding additional treatments as needed to prevent further complications.
5. Continue to manage the patient's cerebrovascular accident and consider adding additional treatments as needed to prevent further neurological deficits.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's urinary tract infection and consider adding additional treatments as needed to prevent further complications.
7. Consider adding additional treatments as needed to manage the patient's hypercarbia and prevent further respiratory complications.
8. Consider adding additional treatments as needed to manage the patient's aspiration and prevent further respiratory complications.

Summary:

The patient is a ventilator-dependent individual with chronic respiratory failure admitted to the ICU. Overnight, they were transitioned from BiPap to a Venturi facemask, which they tolerated well. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98°F (36.7°C), heart rate of 120 bpm, and blood pressure of 127/69 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy via a Venturi mask, with a SpO2 of 89%. The patient's respiratory status is being monitored closely, with an ABG showing a pH of 7.17, PaCO2 of 99 mmHg, and PaO2 of 189 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's chronic respiratory failure and ventilation requirements increase their risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk of developing VAP due to their prolonged ventilation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's chronic respiratory failure and potential underlying infections increase their risk of developing sepsis.
4. Hypoxemia: The patient's SpO2 of 89% indicates hypoxemia, which may require further adjustments to their oxygen therapy.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may indicate underlying cardiac issues that need to be monitored and managed.
6. Bloodstream infections: The patient's indwelling lines and central venous catheters increase their risk of developing bloodstream infections.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's chronic respiratory failure and potential underlying infections increase their risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea and vomiting.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's chronic respiratory failure requires ongoing ICU care, including close monitoring of their respiratory status, oxygen therapy, and ventilation requirements. The patient's nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylactic measures for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP should also be closely monitored and managed.

Based on the provided 24-hour progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, and previous cerebrovascular accident (CVA). She was admitted to the ICU with mental status changes, anorexia, and progressive lethargy, with a work-up concerning for multifocal pneumonia and urinary tract infection (UTI).

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory support: On Venturi facemask with a tidal volume of 242 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 35%.
* Hemodynamics: Tachycardic (120 bpm) with a blood pressure of 127/69 mmHg.
* Electrolytes: Sodium 144 mEq/L, potassium 3.5 mEq/L, and chloride 95 mEq/L.
* Blood gases: pH 7.17, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) 99 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) 66 mmHg.
* Lactic acid level: 1.5 mmol/L.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: Acute on chronic, likely due to multifactorial causes such as chronic hypercarbia, excess volume, infection, and poor respiratory controller function.
2. UTI: Confirmed by urine analysis with hematuria, and a history of Cipro-resistant E. coli.
3. Lethargy/AMS: Minimalizing localizing symptoms, possibly due to hypercarbia, aspiration, viral, or atypical infections.
4. Hypertension: On Diltiazem as an outpatient, but unclear if given today.
5. Peripheral vascular disease: Chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections.
6. Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal and Depakote as an outpatient, but holding medications for altered mental status (AMS).
7. Diverticulosis: History of lower gastrointestinal bleeding (LGIB) in 2014, but no current complaints of pain or bleeding.

The plan for the patient includes:

* Treatment of infection with Vancomycin and Azithromycin.
* Further evaluation of respiratory muscle function with pulmonary function tests (PFTs) and negative inspiratory force (NIF).
* Evaluation for pulmonary embolism (PE) with computed tomography angiography (CTA).
* Monitoring of urine culture and legionella antigen.
* Holding Risperdal and Depakote for AMS.
* Monitoring of valproic acid level.
* Obtaining a peripheral blood sample for hematuria.
* Breaking Diltiazem into short-acting while unclear volume status.
* Monitoring of chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections.
* Extensive neuro exam once the patient is less lethargic.
* Foley catheter in place.
* IV fluids and electrolyte repletion.
* Clear liquids today and advancement of diet with improvement in mental status.
* Prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin.
* Code status: DNR/DNI (confirmed with the patient upon arrival to ICU).

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, sepsis, and hypercarbic respiratory failure. He has a history of chronic respiratory failure, pneumonia, and C-spine injury. He has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin and azithromycin, and has developed a diffuse rash. He is currently on BiPAP and has increased secretions. His vital signs are stable, but he has a fever and his oxygen saturation is 90%. His laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, lactate level, and blood urea nitrogen level.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is a potential complication that requires prompt treatment with antibiotics and supportive care.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management with BiPAP and oxygen therapy.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is a potential complication that requires antibiotic treatment and close monitoring.
4. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management with BiPAP and oxygen therapy.
5. UTI: The patient's UTI is a potential complication that requires antibiotic treatment and close monitoring.
6. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management with antihypertensive medications.
7. Peripheral Vascular Disease: The patient's peripheral vascular disease is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management with compression stockings and physical therapy.
8. Bipolar Disorder: The patient's bipolar disorder is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management with mood stabilizers and antidepressants.
9. Diverticulosis: The patient's diverticulosis is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management with dietary changes and bowel regimen.
10. CVA: The patient's CVA is a potential complication that requires close monitoring and management with physical therapy and speech therapy.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory status, including BiPAP and oxygen therapy. He also requires antibiotic treatment for his pneumonia and UTI, as well as close monitoring of his laboratory results. He requires close monitoring of his blood pressure and management with antihypertensive medications. He also requires close monitoring of his peripheral vascular disease and management with compression stockings and physical therapy. He requires close monitoring of his bipolar disorder and management with mood stabilizers and antidepressants. He requires close monitoring of his diverticulosis and management with dietary changes and bowel regimen. He requires close monitoring of his CVA and management with physical therapy and speech therapy.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics (Vancomycin, Meropenem, and Azithromycin), anticoagulants (Heparin Sodium), and diuretics (Furosemide). They have also been receiving prophylactic treatments for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Based on the provided information, potential medical complications that may arise include:

2. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and they have been receiving antibiotics, which may indicate sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, which may indicate AKI.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's serum calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus levels are abnormal, which may indicate an electrolyte imbalance.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's chest X-ray may show evidence of pneumonia, which may require additional treatment.
6. DVT: The patient is at risk for DVT due to their immobility and the use of prophylactic anticoagulation.
7. Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulcer due to their critical illness and the use of prophylactic medications.
8. VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP due to their mechanical ventilation and the use of prophylactic antibiotics.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, chronic venous stasis changes, and bipolar disorder, admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable urinary tract infection (UTI). She has a tracheostomy and is currently on non-invasive ventilation (NPPV) and intermittent bi-level positive airway pressure (BIPAP). The patient has been experiencing decreased urine output, and her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, mild anemia, and mild thrombocytopenia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 106/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Her respiratory status is being closely monitored, and she is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's medical history is significant for a recent incarcerated hernia repair and failure to wean from mechanical ventilation. She has also had a history of Cipro-resistant E. coli, which may be contributing to her current UTI.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Treatment of PNA with linezolid and aztreonam
* Addition of meropenem to treat allergic reaction
* Venturi facemask and intermittent BIPAP
* Chest physiotherapy
* OOB to chair
* Speech and swallow evaluation
* PFTs and negative inspiratory force evaluation as outpatient
* Azithromycin for Legionella testing
* Urine culture and blood culture as able
* Non-invasive ventilation as needed
* Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to chronic hypercarbia and acute-on-chronic respiratory failure
* UTI progression to sepsis or kidney damage
* Aspiration pneumonia
* Hypertensive crisis
* Thrombocytopenia progression to bleeding or hemorrhage
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Malnutrition
* Skin breakdown due to prolonged immobility and poor wound care
* Infection due to tracheostomy and urinary catheterization
* Cardiovascular complications due to hypertension and chronic venous stasis changes

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI (do not resuscitate/do not intubate), and her disposition is pending clinical improvement.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with a diagnosis of chronic respiratory failure. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), heart rate of 104 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 106/62 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 93% on 50% FiO2.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a decrease in urine output since yesterday evening. The patient was irrigated with 100cc of fluid, which returned pink in color, indicating possible hematuria. The patient received a 1L NS bolus with little change in urine output.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and lactate levels, indicating possible sepsis. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 13 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 7 IU/L. The patient's kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 0.4 mg/dL.

The patient's medication list includes antibiotics, such as vancomycin, meropenem, aztreonam, azithromycin, and linezolid. The patient is also receiving heparin sodium for prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure can lead to worsening respiratory function, including decreased lung compliance, increased airway resistance, and decreased oxygenation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC count and lactate levels indicate possible sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, and cardiovascular instability.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's decreased urine output and elevated creatinine level indicate possible acute kidney injury, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, and cardiovascular instability.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated LFTs indicate possible liver dysfunction, which can lead to coagulopathy, ascites, and encephalopathy.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension indicate possible cardiovascular instability, which can lead to decreased perfusion of vital organs, including the brain, heart, and kidneys.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent these complications and improve their clinical outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with increasingly productive cough, on NPPV much of the time.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratoy Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection.  PNA on CXR. Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission.
   No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated
   hernia repair and failure to wean.  Unclear if aspiration risk but on
   po diet at NS.
   - Treat PNA: now linezolid/aztreonam
   - Venturi FM
   -Discuss recent baseline labs / medication changes with [**Hospital1 169**]/ clarify
   allergies
   - Check Depakote level
   - Check LFTs
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - Treat infection (Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **]); Azithromycin added for atypicals
   - Urine legionella antigen; will d/c azithromycin if legionella
   negative.
   - Sputum / blood culture as able
   - Noninvasive ventilation as needed
   - Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care
   # UTI/HEMATURIA: ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, initially
   thought [**2-1**] to simple UTI but given volume concerning for other
   process. Denying complaints. h/o Cipro-R ecoli.
    - consult urology
    - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
    - intermittent irrigation as needed
    - [**Hospital1 **] hct checks
    - f/u urine cx
   # RASH: likely drug reaction
    - consider derm consult if rash progresses
   # Lethargy/AMS:  Lethargy and minimalizing localizing symptoms.
   Present work-up notable for +UA (with history of Cipro-R E.coli) and
   CXR which appears more volume over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile,
   without leukocytosis.  Family notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider
   aspiration, viral vs atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is
   definately contributing. Resolved with improvement in respiratory
   status.
   - Urine cultures
   - On Venturi facemask now.
   - Valproic acid level
   - Hold Risperdal / Depakote given AMS
   - Monitor with serial ABGs
   # Hypertension: On Diltiazem as outpatient, currently being held given
   pressures.
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder:  On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient.
    - Hold medications for AMS, plan to restart as able.
    - Check Depakote level; holding risperdal and depakote levels.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history. Will plan to discuss with daughter.  [**Name (NI) **] family,
   unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   FEN: IVF o/n (monitor uop), replete electrolytes, NPO while on BiPAP
   - Clear liquids today and advance diet with improvement in mental
   status.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   Access: PIV, A Line
   Code: DNR/DNI  (confirmed with patient upon arrival to ICU)
   Communication: Patient & daughter
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including hypertension, chronic venous stasis changes, and a history of incarceration hernia repair. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable urinary tract infection (UTI).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on non-invasive ventilation (NPPV) and has a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 223, indicating severe respiratory failure.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has hypertension, which is being managed with diltiazem. Her blood pressure is currently 106/62 mmHg.
* Neurological status: The patient is lethargic and has minimalizing localizing symptoms. She has a history of CVA with unknown deficit.
* Renal status: The patient has ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, which is concerning for a UTI. She has a Foley catheter in place.
* Infectious status: The patient has a probable UTI, and urine cultures are pending. She is also at risk for aspiration pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 223, indicating severe respiratory failure. If not managed properly, this can lead to respiratory arrest and death.
2. UTI: The patient's ongoing blood loss in urine is concerning for a UTI. If not treated promptly, this can lead to sepsis and organ failure.
3. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's history of CVA and lethargy puts her at risk for aspiration pneumonia. If not managed properly, this can lead to respiratory failure and death.
4. Sepsis: The patient's probable UTI and ongoing blood loss in urine put her at risk for sepsis. If not managed properly, this can lead to organ failure and death.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's hypertension and history of CVA put her at risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction and heart failure.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of CVA and current lethargic state put her at risk for neurological complications, such as increased intracranial pressure and brain edema.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Treatment of UTI with linezolid and aztreonam.
2. Venturi facemask to improve oxygenation.
3. Intermittent irrigation of Foley catheter to manage blood loss in urine.
4. Serial ABGs to monitor respiratory status.
5. Hold Risperdal and Depakote due to AMS.
6. Monitor for signs of sepsis and respiratory failure.
7. Consult urology and dermatology as needed.
8. Continue bowel regimen and monitor Hct.
9. Plan to discuss goals of care with patient and family.

The patient's disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary of Condition:**

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, CVA with right hemiplegia, PVD, and bipolar disorder. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI. She has a tracheostomy and is on non-invasive ventilation (NPPV) due to chronic hypercarbia. She has a Foley catheter in place for urinary incontinence and is receiving antibiotics for a suspected UTI.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:** The patient's chronic hypercarbia is likely contributing to her respiratory failure. She may require further treatment with ventilatory support and oxygen therapy.
2. **UTI/Hematuria:** The patient's ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine is concerning for a UTI or other process. She may require further evaluation with urine cultures and imaging studies.
3. **Rash:** The patient's rash is likely a drug reaction, but it may also be related to an underlying infection. She may require a dermatology consult if the rash progresses.
4. **Lethargy/AMS:** The patient's lethargy and minimalizing localizing symptoms may be related to her respiratory failure, UTI, or other underlying conditions. She may require further evaluation with serial ABGs and consideration of aspiration, viral, or atypical infections.
5. **Hypertension:** The patient's hypertension is being managed with Diltiazem, but it may require further treatment with antihypertensive medications.
6. **Peripheral Vascular Disease:** The patient's chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections may require further treatment with compression stockings and wound care.
7. **Bipolar Disorder:** The patient's bipolar disorder is being managed with Risperdal and Depakote, but it may require further treatment with mood stabilizers.
8. **Diverticulosis:** The patient's history of LGIB may require further evaluation with colonoscopy or imaging studies.
9. **s/p CVA:** The patient's CVA may have resulted in a permanent deficit, which may require further evaluation with a neurologist.
10. **Urinary Incontinence:** The patient's urinary incontinence may require further treatment with bladder training or medication.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue antibiotics for suspected UTI and monitor for signs of infection.
2. Consider further evaluation with urine cultures, imaging studies, and a dermatology consult for the rash.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider further treatment with ventilatory support and oxygen therapy.
4. Consider further evaluation with serial ABGs and consideration of aspiration, viral, or atypical infections.
5. Continue treatment for hypertension with Diltiazem and consider further treatment with antihypertensive medications.
6. Monitor the patient's peripheral vascular disease and consider further treatment with compression stockings and wound care.
7. Continue treatment for bipolar disorder with Risperdal and Depakote, but consider further treatment with mood stabilizers.
8. Consider further evaluation with colonoscopy or imaging studies for diverticulosis.
9. Consider further evaluation with a neurologist for the patient's s/p CVA.
10. Continue treatment for urinary incontinence with a Foley catheter and consider further treatment with bladder training or medication.

Based on the 24-hour progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, CVA with right hemiplegia, PVD, and bipolar disorder. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI. 

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.7°C, heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 108/62 mmHg. She is receiving mechanical ventilation with a BiPAP mask, and her oxygen saturation is 94%. 

The patient has decreased urine output overnight, despite receiving a 500cc bolus, and continues to drain from the bladder. The urology team is concerned about the possibility of renal cancer and has recommended further investigation, including urine cytology and imaging options. 

The patient's respiratory status is improving, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 183 and a pH of 7.32. Her lactate level is 0.8 mmol/L, and her white blood cell count is 8.5 x 10^9/L. 

The patient has a rash on her posterior, extending to her axillae and anterior chest, which is likely a drug reaction. She is also experiencing lethargy and minimalizing localizing symptoms, which may be related to her hypercarbic respiratory failure, UTI, or aspiration. 

The patient's medications include linezolid, aztreonam, and meropenem for her UTI, as well as Diltiazem for her hypertension. She is also receiving prophylactic heparin for DVT and stress ulcer prophylaxis. 

The patient's disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement, and her code status is DNR/DNI. 

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Renal failure: Given the patient's decreased urine output and concern for renal cancer, it is essential to monitor her renal function closely and consider further investigation, including imaging options.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure is a significant concern, and it is essential to continue to optimize her respiratory therapy and consider further interventions, such as non-invasive ventilation.
3. UTI: The patient's UTI is a significant concern, and it is essential to continue to monitor her urine output and consider further investigation, including urine cytology and imaging options.
4. Lethargy and AMS: The patient's lethargy and minimalizing localizing symptoms may be related to her hypercarbic respiratory failure, UTI, or aspiration, and it is essential to continue to monitor her mental status and consider further investigation, including imaging options.
5. Rash: The patient's rash is likely a drug reaction, and it is essential to continue to monitor her skin and consider further investigation, including dermatology consultation.
6. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is a significant concern, and it is essential to continue to monitor her blood pressure and consider further interventions, such as medication adjustments or invasive hemodynamic monitoring.
7. PVD: The patient's PVD is a significant concern, and it is essential to continue to monitor her peripheral circulation and consider further interventions, such as compression stockings or surgical intervention.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including hypertension, CVA with right hemiplegia, PVD, and bipolar disorder. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on non-invasive ventilation with a Bipap mask, with a pH of 7.32, pCO2 of 70, and pO2 of 64. She has a history of chronic hypercarbia and is suspected to have multifactorial respiratory failure.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's blood pressure is 108/62 mmHg, and her heart rate is 82 bpm. She has a history of hypertension and is currently being held on Diltiazem.
* Renal: The patient has ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, initially thought to be a simple UTI but given volume concerning for other process. She has a history of Cipro-R E. coli.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of diverticulosis and has experienced LGIB in the past. She is currently NPO and has a Foley catheter in place.
* Neurological: The patient has a history of CVA with right hemiplegia and is unable to provide further history. She is currently lethargic and has minimalizing localizing symptoms.
* Skin: The patient has a blanching fine macular rash posteriorly, extending to the axilla bilaterally, and across the anterior chest.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current status include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic hypercarbia and acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure increase her risk of respiratory failure.
* UTI/HEMATURIA: The patient's ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine and history of Cipro-R E. coli increase her risk of UTI and hematuria.
* Renal dysfunction: The patient's history of hypertension and chronic venous stasis changes increase her risk of renal dysfunction.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of diverticulosis and LGIB in the past increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's current lethargic state and minimalizing localizing symptoms increase her risk of neurological deterioration.
* Skin infection: The patient's blanching fine macular rash increases her risk of skin infection.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue linezolid and aztreonam for UTI/HEMATURIA
* Venturi facemask and intermittent BIPAP for respiratory support
* Diurese to manage fluid overload
* Chest PT and OOB to chair to improve respiratory function
* Speech and swallow eval to determine safe PO intake
* PFTs and negative inspiratory force to evaluate respiratory muscle function
* Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care
* Hold medications for AMS and plan to restart as able
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure, UTI/HEMATURIA, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a decreased urine output overnight, despite receiving a 500cc bolus. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.7°C, heart rate of 82 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 108/62 mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a bipap mask and has a respiratory rate of 20 inspirations per minute. The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase level, indicating possible infection and organ dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to decreased urine output and potential sepsis.
2. Sepsis-induced organ dysfunction, including respiratory failure, cardiovascular instability, and coagulopathy.
3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility and potential hypercoagulability.
5. Stress ulcer bleeding due to increased cortisol levels and potential gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to altered glucose metabolism and potential insulin resistance.
7. Electrolyte imbalance due to changes in fluid balance, electrolyte shifts, and potential medication side effects.
8. Cardiovascular instability due to sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, or cardiac tamponade.
9. Respiratory failure due to worsening lung function, respiratory muscle weakness, or aspiration pneumonia.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or identify these potential complications and provide timely interventions to improve the patient's outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, chronic venous stasis changes, Proteus wound infections, bipolar disorder, diverticulosis, and a recent CVA with residual deficits. She was admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on non-invasive ventilation (NPPV) and has a moderate hypercarbic respiratory failure with a pH of 7.32, pCO2 of 70, and pO2 of 64. She has a history of chronic hypercarbia and may have excess volume and infection contributing to her current condition.
* Renal: The patient has ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, initially thought to be a simple UTI but now considered concerning for other processes. She has a history of Cipro-resistant E. coli and is currently on antibiotics.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hypertension and is on Diltiazem, which is currently being held due to high pressures.
* Neurological: The patient has a recent CVA with residual deficits and is unable to provide further history. She is unable to move her right arm and is not ambulatory.
* Skin: The patient has a rash, likely due to a drug reaction, and is being considered for a dermatology consult.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Acute kidney injury due to ongoing blood loss in urine
* Sepsis due to the UTI and pneumonia
* Respiratory failure due to the hypercarbic respiratory failure
* Cardiac complications due to the hypertension and potential cardiac strain
* Neurological complications due to the recent CVA and potential aspiration
* Skin complications due to the rash and potential infection

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing antibiotics for the UTI and pneumonia
* Intermittent irrigation of the bladder to manage the blood loss
* Non-invasive ventilation to manage the hypercarbic respiratory failure
* Monitoring of the patient's respiratory and cardiac status
* Regular checks of the patient's neurological status
* Consideration of a dermatology consult for the rash
* Holding of Diltiazem and Depakote due to high pressures and AMS
* Re-checking of ammonia levels on Friday morning labs
* Monitoring of the patient's blood glucose levels
* Clear liquids today and advancement of diet with improvement in mental status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a complex medical history, including hypertension, chronic venous stasis changes, bipolar disorder, diverticulosis, and a history of CVA with residual hemiplegia. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure, probable UTI, and pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on non-invasive ventilation (BIPAP) and has a history of chronic hypercarbia. She has a mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension and a probable diastolic dysfunction.
2. UTI/Hematuria: The patient has ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, initially thought to be a simple UTI but given volume concerning for other processes. She has a history of Cipro-R E.coli.
3. Lethargy/AMS: The patient is lethargic and minimally localizing symptoms. She has a history of coughing, and the family notes that she has been coughing. The patient's work-up is notable for +UA (with history of Cipro-R E.coli) and CXR, which appears more volume-overloaded than true PNA.
4. RASH: The patient has a likely drug reaction, which appears to be resolving.
5. Low urine output: The patient has low urine output despite boluses and normal MAP.
6. Hypertension: The patient is on Diltiazem as an outpatient, but it is being held due to pressures.
7. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient has chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections.
8. Bipolar disorder: The patient is on Risperdal and Depakote as an outpatient, but these medications are being held due to AMS.
9. Diverticulosis: The patient has a history of LGIB and is currently asymptomatic.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate further, leading to respiratory arrest or need for intubation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's UTI/Hematuria can progress to sepsis, leading to organ dysfunction and increased mortality.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension and probable diastolic dysfunction can lead to cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's history of CVA with residual hemiplegia and current lethargy/AMS can lead to further neurological decline or complications such as seizures.
5. Infection: The patient's UTI/Hematuria can lead to bacteremia or sepsis, which can increase her risk of mortality.
6. Renal failure: The patient's low urine output and history of chronic kidney disease can lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease progression.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diverticulosis and history of LGIB can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue linezolid and aztreonam for UTI/Hematuria.
2. Venturi FM/Intermittent BIPAP for respiratory failure.
3. Diuresis with IV lasix for low urine output.
4. Monitor for signs of sepsis or infection.
5. Hold Risperdal and Depakote for AMS.
6. Continue non-invasive ventilation as needed.
7. Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care.

The patient's disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement, likely transfer to MACU in the next few days.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, CVA with right hemiplegia, peripheral vascular disease, and bipolar disorder. She was admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI. She has a tracheostomy and is on non-invasive ventilation. Her current medications include linezolid, aztreonam, diltiazem, metoprolol, and lasix.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.8°C, heart rate of 94 bpm, blood pressure of 135/86 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 92%. Her respiratory support includes a bipap mask, CPAP/PSV mode, and FiO2 of 35%.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, mild thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate levels. Her cardiac enzymes are normal, and her troponin levels are <0.01 ng/mL.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Hypercarbic respiratory failure: acute on chronic, likely multifactorial
* UTI: ongoing, with moderate blood loss in urine
* Low urine output: suspecting renal dysfunction/hematuria
* Lethargy/AMS: likely due to hypercarbia, aspiration, or viral infection
* RASH: likely drug reaction, appears to be resolving
* Hypertension: on Diltiazem, currently being held given pressures
* Peripheral vascular disease: patient known chronic venous stasis changes & Proteus wound infections
* Diverticulosis: patient h/o LGIB, no c/o of pain at this time to indicate inflammation

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue linezolid and aztreonam
* Venturi FM/ intermittent BIPAP
* Pt diuresed with 60 mg IV lasix yesterday, negative approx 500 cc for the day
* OOB to chair
* Repeat S+S eval as Pt refusing NG tube and PEG, and currently significant aspiration risk
* PFTs and negative inspiratory force as outpatient to evaluate respiratory muscle function
* Sputum/blood culture as able
* Continue non-invasive ventilation as needed
* Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Pneumonia: given the patient's history of chronic respiratory failure and probable UTI
* Sepsis: given the patient's ongoing UTI and low urine output
* Aspiration: given the patient's significant aspiration risk and refusal of NG tube and PEG
* Respiratory failure: given the patient's acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure
* Cardiac complications: given the patient's history of hypertension and mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension
* Gastrointestinal complications: given the patient's history of diverticulosis and LGIB
* Neurological complications: given the patient's history of CVA and ongoing lethargy/AMS

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiovascular: The patient has likely diastolic congestive heart failure (dCHF) with an ejection fraction (LVEF) > 75%. The patient is receiving various medications, including metoprolol, diltiazem, and heparin sodium.
* Respiratory: The patient is receiving respiratory support with a bipap mask, CPAP/PSV mode, and oxygen delivery at 35%. The patient's vital signs indicate a respiratory rate of 33 breaths per minute, and their arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.39, pCO2 of 67, and pO2 of 226.
* Neurological: The patient's neurological status is not fully assessed due to the lack of information on their response to stimuli, movement, tone, and other neurological parameters.
* Laboratory results: The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. The patient's troponin-T levels are below 0.01, indicating no myocardial infarction.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and their ABG results indicate mild respiratory acidosis. Close monitoring of their respiratory status is necessary to prevent further deterioration.
* Urinary tract infection (UTI): The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count and lactate dehydrogenase levels, which may indicate a UTI. Further investigation and treatment are necessary to prevent complications.
* Atrial fibrillation (AFIB): The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) results show AFIB, which may increase their risk of cardiovascular complications. Close monitoring of their cardiac status is necessary to prevent further complications.
* Sepsis: The patient's laboratory results show elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels, which may indicate sepsis. Close monitoring of their vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to prevent further complications.
* Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's glucose levels are elevated, which may indicate diabetic ketoacidosis. Close monitoring of their glucose levels and treatment with insulin or other medications may be necessary to prevent further complications.

In conclusion, the patient's current condition is complex, and close monitoring of their vital signs, laboratory results, and treatment is necessary to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI. She has a history of chronic venous stasis changes, bipolar disorder, and peripheral vascular disease.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: She is receiving non-invasive ventilation (NIPPV) and has a pH of 7.39, pCO2 of 67, and pO2 of 79. Her SpO2 is 92% on a bipap mask.
* Cardiovascular status: She has atrial fibrillation, which is new and has no history of AF. Her cardiac enzymes are negative.
* Neurological status: She is somnolent and arousable with name calling and sternal rub, but does not answer simple questions. She has chronic venous stasis changes on her legs.
* Renal status: She has ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, initially thought to be a simple UTI, but given the volume, it is concerning for other processes. Her urine output has improved on Lasix.
* Nutritional status: She is unable to take PO safely and is refusing Dobhoff and PEG.
* Skin status: She has a rash, likely a drug reaction, and her back appears somewhat more red in dependent areas.
* Hematological status: Her WBC is 9.4, Hct is 42.1, and platelet count is 134.
* Laboratory results: Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and her lactate level is 0.9 mmol/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still compromised, and she may require further interventions to improve her oxygenation and ventilation.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiac complications, such as embolization or arrhythmias.
* Neurological complications: The patient's somnolent state and inability to answer simple questions may indicate a neurological complication, such as a stroke or encephalopathy.
* Renal complications: The patient's ongoing blood loss in urine and history of chronic kidney disease may lead to further renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease progression.
* Skin complications: The patient's rash may worsen or develop into a more severe skin condition, such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's inability to take PO safely and refusal of Dobhoff and PEG may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as malnutrition or aspiration.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue non-invasive ventilation and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
* Manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with IV diltiazem and consider further interventions, such as cardioversion or anticoagulation.
* Perform a thorough neurological examination to assess the patient's cognitive and motor function.
* Monitor the patient's renal status closely and consider further interventions, such as diuretics or dialysis.
* Continue to monitor the patient's skin status and consider a dermatology consult if the rash worsens.
* Consider a gastroenterology consult to assess the patient's nutritional status and develop a plan for safe and effective nutrition.
* Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and consider further interventions, such as potassium supplementation or diuretics, as needed.
* Consider a social work consult to discuss the patient's goals of care and develop a plan for end-of-life care, if necessary.

Based on the 24-hour progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, chronic venous stasis changes, Proteus wound infections, bipolar disorder, diverticulosis, and a previous CVA with residual deficits. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, and has since developed atrial fibrillation, lethargy, and a rash.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: Stable, with a respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 91% on a bipap mask.
* Cardiovascular: In atrial fibrillation, with a heart rate of 98 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 142/86 mmHg.
* Neurological: Lethargic, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10.
* Renal: Ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, with a urinary output of 1,930 mL over the past 24 hours.
* Hematological: Hemoglobin of 11.8 g/dL, hematocrit of 38.8%, and platelet count of 122,000/mL.
* Electrolytes: Sodium of 140 mEq/L, potassium of 3.5 mEq/L, and chloride of 95 mEq/L.
* Blood cultures: Negative.
* Urine cultures: Positive for E. coli.

The patient's medications include:

* Linezolid and aztreonam for UTI
* Diltiazem for atrial fibrillation
* Lasix for fluid overload
* Heparin sodium for prophylaxis
* Metoprolol and furosemide for heart failure
* Ativan for agitation
* Depakote for bipolar disorder (held due to elevated ammonia levels)
* Risperdal for bipolar disorder (held due to AMS)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to hypercarbia and chronic lung disease
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to atrial fibrillation
* Sepsis due to UTI
* Renal failure due to fluid overload and underlying chronic kidney disease
* Bleeding due to platelet dysfunction and coagulopathy
* Infection due to indwelling catheters and central lines
* Delirium due to AMS and underlying medical conditions
* Nutritional deficiencies due to poor oral intake and malabsorption
* Pressure ulcers due to prolonged immobility and poor skin care

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued treatment for UTI with linezolid and aztreonam
* Monitoring of atrial fibrillation with serial electrocardiograms and echocardiograms
* Management of fluid overload with diuretics and fluid restriction
* Monitoring of respiratory status with serial arterial blood gas analyses
* Nutritional support with total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and enteral nutrition
* Skin care and pressure ulcer prevention with regular turning and repositioning
* Pain management with opioids and non-pharmacological interventions
* Family meeting to discuss goals of care and advance care planning.

Based on the 24-hour progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 78-year-old woman with a history of chronic hypertension, CVA with right hemiplegia, PVD, and bipolar disorder. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI. The patient has a tracheostomy in place and is on non-invasive ventilation. She has a history of aspiration risk and is on a diet at NS.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 35.9°C (96.7°F)
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (78-108)
* Blood pressure: 142/86 mmHg (110-149/124-136)
* Respiratory rate: 29 breaths per minute (17-41)
* SpO2: 91%

Laboratory results:

* White blood cell count: 9.1 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 11.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 122 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.3 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* TCO2: 42 mmHg
* Glucose: 64 mg/dL

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's baseline HCO3 level is 30, and it has increased to 38 on admission. She has radiographic evidence of PNA on CXR.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient developed new AF as of this morning, with no history of AF per documentation. She is on IV diltiazem 10 q6 if HR>160 prn.
3. Lethargy/AMS: The patient was more disoriented after getting a low dose of Ativan for agitation overnight. She has a history of Cipro-R E. coli and CXR appears more volume-overloaded than true PNA.
4. UTI/HEMATURIA: The patient has ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, initially thought to be a simple UTI but given volume concerning for other process. She has a history of Cipro-R ecoli.
5. Low urine output: The patient has improved on Lasix, with a goal of -1L today.
6. Rash: The patient has a likely drug reaction, with the rash appearing more red in dependent areas.
7. Hypertension: The patient is on Diltiazem as an outpatient, but it is being held given pressures.
8. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient has chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections.
9. Bipolar disorder: The patient is on Risperdal/Depakote as an outpatient, but these medications are being held due to AMS.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure can worsen, leading to respiratory arrest.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, and her hypertension can increase the risk of cardiac events.
3. Infection: The patient's UTI can spread to other parts of the body, and her history of Cipro-R ecoli increases the risk of further infections.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of LGIB and diverticulosis increases the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's history of CVA and PVD increases the risk of further neurological deficits.
6. Renal complications: The patient's history of hypertension and PVD increases the risk of renal failure.
7. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's history of bleeding diathesis increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue linezolid/aztreonam for the patient's UTI and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
2. Continue diuresis with Lasix to improve urine output.
3. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust antihypertensive medications as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
5. Consider a dermatology consult for the patient's rash.
6. Consider a cardiology consult for the patient's atrial fibrillation.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust medications as needed.
8. Consider a urology consult for the patient's UTI and hematuria.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust medications as needed.
10. Consider a social work consult to discuss the patient's goals of care and advance care planning.

   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Unclear if aspiration risk but on po diet at NS.  Ammonia level
   has come down since stopping depakote.  Failed S&S test.
   - Follow ABG
   - Continue linezolid/aztreonam
   - Venturi FM/ Intermittent BIPAP
   -  Lasix 20 mg IV today
   - OOB to chair
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - F/U culture
   - Continue noninvasive ventilation as needed
   - Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care
   # Nutritional Status:  Failed speech and swallow and has refused
   Dobhoff/PEG.  Discussed TPN, however this is not an effective bridge to
   a definitive therapy.
   -  Have speech evaluate today
   - Continue to discuss with family
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF v. PVCs on [**3-10**]. No history of AF per
   documentation. On IV dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 prn.  Was given lopressor ,
   however may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE
   negative.  TSH normal
   - Continue diuresis
   - Give diltiazem IV prn for tachycardia, avoid beta blocker as may have
   worsened her resp. status
   - cycle cardiac enzymes--
 negative X3
   # Lethargy/AMS:  Pt. more disoriented after getting low dose of Ativan
   for agitation overnight [**3-10**].  Present work-up notable for +UA (with
   history of Cipro-R E.coli) and CXR which appears more volume
   over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile, without leukocytosis.  Family
   notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider aspiration, viral vs
   atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is definitely contributing.
   Resolved with improvement in respiratory status.
   - DC ativan and add to allergy list
   - F/U Urine cultures
   - On Venturi facemask now.
   - Holding depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   - Ammonia level normalized now. Suspect adverse effect from Depakote
   - Monitor with serial ABGs
   # UTI/HEMATURIA: ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, initially
   thought [**2-1**] to simple UTI but given volume concerning for other
   process. No clots. Denying complaints. h/o Cipro-R ecoli.
   - defer more extensive w/u to outpatient provided pt remains stable
   - will defer urology c/s at this time
   - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
   - intermittent irrigation as needed
   - QD hct checks
   - f/u urine cx
   - Outpatient urology w/u
   # Low urine output
 Improved on Lasix
   - Continue Lasix with goal of -500cc today.
   # RASH: likely drug reaction, back appears somewhat more red in
   dependent areas
    - continue to monitor and consider derm consult if worsening
   # Hypertension: On Diltiazem as outpatient, currently being held given
   pressures.
   - Holding Dilt, but can restart if Pt tachycardic or hypertensive
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient.
    - Hold medications for AMS, plan to restart as able.
    - Check Depakote level; holding risperdal and depakote.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history.  Per family, unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, diurese, replete electrolytes, NPO
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   Access: PIV, A Line, PICC
   Code: DNR/DNI  (confirmed with patient upon arrival to ICU)

Based on the progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, CVA with right hemiplegia, PVD, and bipolar disorder. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI. She has been on non-invasive ventilation and has shown improvement in her respiratory status.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and neutrophils
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and creatinine (Cr)
* Normal electrolytes and blood urea nitrogen (BUN)
* Elevated ammonia level, which has normalized since stopping Depakote
* Normal cardiac enzymes and troponin-T

The patient's medications include:

* Linezolid and aztreonam for UTI
* Diltiazem for atrial fibrillation
* Lasix for fluid management
* Ativan for agitation
* Depakote for bipolar disorder (held due to elevated ammonia level)

The patient's potential medical complications are:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's chronic hypercarbia is likely contributing to her respiratory failure. She requires continued non-invasive ventilation and close monitoring of her respiratory status.
2. UTI: The patient's UTI is ongoing, and she requires continued antibiotics and close monitoring of her urine output and culture results.
3. Lethargy/AMS: The patient's lethargy is likely due to her hypercarbic respiratory failure and may be contributing to her inability to provide further history. She requires close monitoring of her mental status and respiratory status.
4. RASH: The patient has a likely drug reaction to one of her medications, which requires close monitoring and potential dermatology consult.
5. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is being managed with Diltiazem, which is being held due to her tachycardia. She requires close monitoring of her blood pressure and cardiac status.
6. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient has chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections, which require close monitoring and potential dermatology consult.
7. Bipolar disorder: The patient's bipolar disorder is being managed with Risperdal and Depakote, which are being held due to her AMS. She requires close monitoring of her mental status and potential restarting of her medications.
8. Diverticulosis: The patient has a history of LGIB, but is currently asymptomatic. She requires close monitoring of her bowel regimen and potential restarting of her medications.
9. s/p CVA: The patient has a history of CVA with right hemiplegia, which requires close monitoring of her neurologic status and potential restarting of her medications.

The patient's potential medical complications that may arise in the next 24 hours include:

* Worsening of her hypercarbic respiratory failure
* Development of sepsis or organ failure due to her UTI
* Further worsening of her AMS
* Development of a rash or skin reaction due to her medications
* Worsening of her hypertension or cardiac status
* Development of bleeding due to her diverticulosis
* Further worsening of her peripheral vascular disease

   Assessment and Plan
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with increasingly productive cough, on NPPV much of the time.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Unclear if aspiration risk but on po diet at NS.  Ammonia level
   has come down since stopping depakote.  Failed S&S test.
   - Follow ABG
   - Continue linezolid/aztreonam
   - Venturi FM/ Intermittent BIPAP
   -  Lasix 20 mg IV today
   - OOB to chair
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - F/U culture
   - Continue noninvasive ventilation as needed
   - Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care
   # Nutritional Status:  Failed speech and swallow and has refused
   Dobhoff/PEG.  Discussed TPN, however this is not an effective bridge to
   a definitive therapy.
   -  Have speech evaluate today
   - Continue to discuss with family
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF v. PVCs on [**3-10**]. No history of AF per
   documentation. On IV dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 prn.  Was given lopressor ,
   however may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE
   negative.  TSH normal
   - Continue diuresis
   - Give diltiazem IV prn for tachycardia, avoid beta blocker as may have
   worsened her resp. status
   - cycle cardiac enzymes--
 negative X3
   # Lethargy/AMS:  Pt. more disoriented after getting low dose of Ativan
   for agitation overnight [**3-10**].  Present work-up notable for +UA (with
   history of Cipro-R E.coli) and CXR which appears more volume
   over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile, without leukocytosis.  Family
   notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider aspiration, viral vs
   atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is definitely contributing.
   Resolved with improvement in respiratory status.
   - DC ativan and add to allergy list
   - F/U Urine cultures
   - On Venturi facemask now.
   - Holding depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   - Ammonia level normalized now. Suspect adverse effect from Depakote
   - Monitor with serial ABGs
   # UTI/HEMATURIA: ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, initially
   thought [**2-1**] to simple UTI but given volume concerning for other
   process. No clots. Denying complaints. h/o Cipro-R ecoli.
   - defer more extensive w/u to outpatient provided pt remains stable
   - will defer urology c/s at this time
   - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
   - intermittent irrigation as needed
   - QD hct checks
   - f/u urine cx
   - Outpatient urology w/u
   # Low urine output
 Improved on Lasix
   - Continue Lasix with goal of -500cc today.
   # RASH: likely drug reaction, back appears somewhat more red in
   dependent areas
    - continue to monitor and consider derm consult if worsening
   # Hypertension: On Diltiazem as outpatient, currently being held given
   pressures.
   - Holding Dilt, but can restart if Pt tachycardic or hypertensive
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient.
    - Hold medications for AMS, plan to restart as able.
    - Check Depakote level; holding risperdal and depakote.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history.  Per family, unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, diurese, replete electrolytes, NPO
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   Access: PIV, A Line, PICC
   Code: DNR/DNI  (confirmed with patient upon arrival to ICU)
   Communication: Patient & daughter [**Name (NI) 1040**]
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement; likely transfer to MACU
   in next few days
   ------ Protected Section ------
   CC: resp failure
   MICU ATTENDING ADDENDUM
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   team for the key portions of the services provided. I agree with the
   note above, including the assessment and plan. I would emphasize and
   add the following points:
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure in the setting of BLL
   pneumonia, probably due to aspiration. Back in NSR, echo with small LV,
   elevated EF, mild PHTN.
   Exam notable for Tm 96.7 BP 140/73 HR 78-108 RR 22 with sat 92 on
   0.35FM 7.32/78/86 on FM. Intermittently requiring NIPPV for hypercarbic
   resp failure with mental status changes. TBB -550cc/24.
   Currently awake, alert, smiling, responding to questions. Coarse BS,
   [**Month (only) **] B bases. RRR s1s2. Soft +BS, chronic stasis changes. Diffuse
   erythematous blanching rash, stable according to house staff.
   Labs notable for WBC 6K, HCT 40, K+ 3.5, Cr 0.3. CXR unchanged BLL ASD.
   Agree with plan to manage acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory
   failure with NPPV PRN, though currently well on FM, continue treatment
   of HAP with linezolid / aztronam as well as repeat lasix for pulmonary
   edema.
   For AF c RVR - dilt IV, gentle diuresis; could add dig if rate remains
   high and BP trends down. Gross hematuria has resolved. Failed S+S - pt
   / family does not want doboff or PEG. Will discuss with pt and family
   that she could try thickened dysphagia diet at risk of aspiration and
   death, or will be NPO given her requests. OOB to chair. CM to screen
   for LTAC level of care. DNR/I. Remainder of plan as outlined above.
   Patient is critically ill
